raw_text:
More reforms ahead says Milburn
 
 Labour will continue to pursue controversial reforms if it wins a third term in power, the party's election chief Alan Milburn has said.
 
 He pledged Labour would encourage more people to achieve their aspirations. "What we want is for more people to earn and own," Mr Milburn told BBC Radio 4's Today show. Tory Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin called Labour "a brilliant machine for talking about things" but said it did not deliver policies the country needs. Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrats' President Simon Hughes said: "New Labour has lost people's confidence in a way Old Labour never did." Mr Milburn told Today that Labour wanted policies which encouraged increased social mobility in Britain.
 
 Pressed on incapacity benefits, he said the tax and welfare system must "provide the right incentives to people". "No-one is talking about driving people into work but what we do know is there are one million people on incapacity benefit who want the opportunity to work, providing the right level of support is there for them". However, backbench Labour MP Karen Buck warned against proposed changes in such benefits. She told the Today programme: "If the policy is seen as being about how do you make the feckless poor go back to work then it is not going to work, on the one hand. And it is not going to improve our electoral chances on the other." Mr Milburn also sought to draw a line under the controversy about reports of a feud between Gordon Brown and Prime Minister Tony Blair.
 
 He stressed that Mr Brown would play the same role that he did in the last election. Mr Milburn gave more details of planned reforms in a speech to Labour's Fabian Society, in which he also praised Mr Brown as one of the leaders of the party's reform process. In the speech, he backed choice in schools and hospitals, wider home ownership and changes to the welfare system. Mr Milburn insisted that government reform must continue. "Our task is to rebuild the New Labour coalition around 'one nation politics' that recognise, while life is hard for many, all should have the chance to succeed," he said. "There is a glass ceiling on opportunity in this country. In our first two terms we have raised it. In our third term we have to break it." Voters turned on the party when it failed to reform industrial relations in the 1960s, he also told his audience.
 
 Oliver Letwin said the government had failed to deliver in any of the key public services, such as cleaner hospitals, discipline in schools and putting more police on the streets. He said ministers had not delivered cleaner hospitals, with 5,000 people dying from infections last year. New Labour had failed on school discipline because it had not implemented serious reforms so that teachers could run schools, and which would give parents choice, he went on. For the Lib Dems, Simon Hughes said many pensioners are means tested for the money they needed and students who were told there wouldn't be tuition fees and more debt "have been given exactly the opposite". He added: "Under New Labour, all households are still paying unfair council tax rather than a fairer alternative."
llama3.2:1b: Labour will continue to pursue reforms after winning three terms in power.
Alan Milburn said Labour would encourage people to achieve their aspirations by encouraging increased social mobility and providing incentives for work.
However, backbench MP Karen Buck warned against proposed changes to incapacity benefits, which she felt could make the poor return to work without sufficient support.
Labour also sought to draw a line under controversy surrounding reports of a feud between Gordon Brown and Tony Blair.
Milburn praised Brown as one of Labour's leaders in reforming the party during their previous election.
He emphasized that government reform must continue to rebuild the "New Labour coalition" around policies recognizing opportunity for all.
Oliver Letwin criticized Labour's failure to deliver reforms in key areas such as cleaner hospitals, discipline in schools, and more police on the streets.
New Labour failed to implement serious school reforms that would give parents choice.
Simon Hughes from the Lib Dems criticized Labour's means-testing policy for pensioners, which he felt made it difficult for students to access affordable education.
Simon Hughes also questioned Liberal Democrat policies on council tax, saying it disproportionately affects low-income households and does not provide a fair alternative.
llama3.2:3b: Labour will continue to pursue reforms if it wins a third term in power.
The party wants to encourage more people to achieve their aspirations and increase social mobility in Britain.
Proposed policies include changing the tax and welfare system, introducing choice in schools and hospitals, wider home ownership, and changes to the welfare system.
gemma2:2b: Labour plans to continue controversial reforms if re-elected.
They believe in encouraging social mobility through policies like increased home ownership and greater support for work.
There is controversy regarding proposed changes to incapacity benefits, with some members expressing concerns about the potential negative impact on voter sentiment.
Alan Milburn emphasized that Gordon Brown will maintain his role as a key leader during the next term.
He highlighted planned reforms such as choice in schools and hospitals, and a revised welfare system.
He also emphasized the need for continued government reform through 'one nation politics' to break down social barriers and create opportunities.
Labour argues they have raised the glass ceiling on opportunity, while critics point to failures across public services like healthcare and education.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In his speech to the Fabian Society, Labour leader Alan Milburn highlighted plans for reforms to tackle pressing issues like industrial relations, housing, and pension schemes.

He emphasized that government should continue to work towards rebuilding the New Labour coalition focused on "one nation politics" by promoting choice in education, home ownership, and a more balanced welfare system.

While praising Gordon Brown as "one of the leaders of the party's reform process," Milburn warned about the ongoing challenges faced by many citizens and suggested that government must continue to address structural issues within society.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Labour plans to pursue reforms including increased social mobility, improved incentives for work through changes in the tax and welfare system.
It also reaffirms its commitment to one-nation politics and choice in schools and hospitals, as well as breaking glass ceilings on opportunity in the country.

However, Labour faces criticism over incapacity benefits, particularly from backbench MPs who worry about the policy being seen as about forcing people into work rather than addressing their need for support.
qwen2.5:3b: Labour will continue pursuing controversial reforms if it wins power again, according to election chief Alan Milburn.
He pledged to encourage increased social mobility and provided incentives for people to work.
However, he also acknowledged the need to support those who want to stay at home.
Milburn defended Labour's policies against claims of inaction from opposition parties like the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats.
He stressed that government reform must continue, particularly in areas such as education and welfare, with a focus on breaking down "glass ceilings" for opportunity.
Milburn also addressed concerns about industrial relations failures under New Labour, suggesting they should learn from past mistakes.

If Mr Brown plays the same role that he did in the last election, Mr Milburn gave more details of planned reforms in a speech to Labour's Fabian Society.

New Labour had failed on school discipline because it had not implemented serious reforms so that teachers could run schools, and which would give parents choice.

For the Lib Dems, Simon Hughes said many pensioners are means tested for the money they needed and students who were told there wouldn't be tuition fees and more debt "have been given exactly the opposite".
Under New Labour, all households are still paying unfair council tax rather than a fairer alternative.

More reforms ahead says Milburn

He pledged Labour would encourage more people to achieve their aspirations.
"What we want is for more people to earn and own," Mr Milburn told BBC Radio 4's Today show.
Tory Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin called Labour "a brilliant machine for talking about things" but said it did not deliver policies the country needs.
Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrats' President Simon Hughes said: "New Labour has lost people's confidence in a way Old Labour never did."
Mr Milburn told Today that Labour wanted policies which encouraged increased social mobility in Britain.
Pressed on incapacity benefits, he said the tax and welfare system must "provide the right incentives to people".

"No-one is talking about driving people into work but what we do know is there are one million people on incapacity benefit who want the opportunity to work, providing the right level of support is there for them," Mr Milburn told Today.

He added: "If the policy is seen as being about how do you make the feckless poor go back to work then it is not going to work, on the one hand and it is not going to improve our electoral chances on the other."
tinyllama:1.1b: In response to the statement by Labour Party leader Alan Milburn that he hopes the party will continue pursuing controversial reforms in order to win the third term in power, Liberal Democrats President Simon Hughes warned that such policies may not have the desired effect of improving people's lives.

Milburn also praised Prime Minister Gordon Brown for his leadership during the party's reform process and suggested that reform will continue in areas such as choice in schools and wider home ownership.
Meanwhile, Labour MP Karen Buck criticized proposed changes to benefits and warned against proposing policies aimed at driving poor people into work.

Milburn backed choice in schools and hospital reform and claimed the party's task was to "rebuild New Labour coalition around 'one nation politics'" that recognizes opportunities but also sees life as hard for many.
Letwin said the government had failed on cleaning hospitals, maintaining schools, putting more police on the streets, and discriminating against sick people in terms of cleaner hospital care.
Hughes also raised concerns about means-testing for financial aid and students receiving extra debt.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary provided above is an in-depth analysis of the text focusing on key aspects such as reforms in the welfare system, increased social mobility, and the role of Tony Blair in the Labour party's reform process.
It also provides information about Liberal Democrat president Simon Hughes' comments on New Labour's performance on the topic of pensioners, students, and debt.
The text discusses how Labour will continue to implement controversial reforms if it wins a third term in government, as well as the party's policy on choosing schools and hospitals.

This summary concludes by highlighting that New Labour did not meet expectations regarding cleanliness, discipline in educational institutions, and the allocation of funds for pensioners and students respectively.
phi:2.7b: Labour's election chief Alan Milburn says that if the party wins a third term in power, it will continue to pursue controversial reforms.
In an interview with BBC Radio 4's Today show, Mr Milburn pledged Labour would encourage more people to achieve their aspirations.
He wants to see more people earning and owning property.
However, there are concerns about proposed changes to incapacity benefits, with some politicians warning that the policy is not effective.
Meanwhile, there has been criticism of New Labour's approach to reform in education, healthcare, and welfare.
Despite this, Mr Milburn insists that government reforms must continue.
He believes that New Labour has raised the "glass ceiling" on opportunity by implementing policies to increase social mobility.
However, voters have turned against the party when it failed to implement industrial relations reforms in the early 2000s.

He pledged that Labour would encourage more people to achieve their aspirations and wants policies that encourage increased social mobility in Britain.
However, Tory Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin criticized Labour for not delivering policies the country needs.
Liberal Democrats' President Simon Hughes said New Labour has lost people's confidence in a way Old Labour never did.
Milburn sought to draw a line under the controversy about reports of a feud between Gordon Brown and Prime Minister Tony Blair.
He praised former Prime Minister Gordon Brown as one of the leaders of the party's reform process.
Milburn also backed choice in schools and hospitals, wider home ownership and changes to the welfare system.
hermes3:3b: Labour plans to continue controversial reforms if re-elected, says Milburn; aims for increased social mobility in Britain through right incentives.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Labor will continue to pursue reforms in its third term if it wins, focusing on encouraging social mobility and providing incentives for people to work through the tax and welfare system.
Labour's election chief, Alan Milburn, discussed plans for increased choice in schools and hospitals, wider home ownership, and changes to the welfare system.
Meanwhile, Tory Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin criticized Labour for not delivering key public services, such as cleaner hospitals and disciplined schools.
The Liberal Democrats' President Simon Hughes commented on the unfairness of New Labour's policies towards means-tested pensioners and students with tuition fees and debt.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Labour's election chief, Alan Milburn, stated that if re-elected, the party would continue pursuing controversial reforms aimed at increasing social mobility.
He emphasized policies encouraging people to "earn and own" and defended welfare system changes to provide better incentives for work.
However, Labour MP Karen Buck warned against reforms that might be perceived as forcing the poor into work.
Milburn also dismissed reports of a feud between Gordon Brown and Tony Blair, affirming Brown's continued role in the party.
In a speech, Milburn supported school and hospital choice, home ownership expansion, and welfare changes, stressing the need to break barriers to opportunity.
Conservative Oliver Letwin criticized Labour for failing to improve key public services, citing issues like hospital infections, school discipline, and policing.
Liberal Democrat Simon Hughes argued that Labour had lost public trust, pointing to pensioner means-testing, student debt, and unfair council tax.
stablelm2:1.6b: Labour party, led by Alan Milburn, will continue pursuing reforms if they win a third term in power.
They aim to encourage social mobility and increase support for those with incapacity benefits.

Mr. Milburn emphasizes that the government reform must continue rebuilding the "New Labour coalition" around one nation politics, recognizing that everyone should have the chance to succeed despite facing challenges.
Some critics argue that proposed changes in benefits could negatively impact voter interest.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Labour, under Alan Milburn's leadership, plans to push ahead with controversial reforms if it secures another term.
The party aims to boost social mobility and encourage more people to achieve their aspirations by earning and owning assets.
Key areas of focus include supporting increased home ownership, wider school choice, and welfare system overhauls.
Milburn emphasizes the need for policies that provide incentives for those on incapacity benefits who want to work.
However, he warns against policies perceived as punitive or designed solely to force individuals back into employment.
Opponents argue that Labour has lost public trust, similar to Old Labour's situation.

Critics, such as Conservative Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin and Liberal Democrats' President Simon Hughes, contend that the government has failed in delivering essential public services like clean hospitals, effective school discipline, and improved community safety.
They also criticize means-testing for pensioners and students, claiming it imposes unfair burdens on households.
Milburn seeks to rebuild the New Labour coalition around "one nation politics" that ensures equal opportunities for all, challenging the glass ceiling limiting opportunity in Britain.
He stresses the importance of continuing government reform to break this barrier.
